figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: Chemical structures of selected polyphenolic compounds showing anti-NMSC effect.

figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: Mechanisms of resveratrol action [97,98,99,100,101,102,103,104,105,106] (parts of the figure were drawn by using pictures from Servier Medical Art).

figure_3.title: Figure 3.
figure_3.caption: Chemical structures of selected flavonoids showing an anti-NMSC effect. EGCG—epigallocatechin gallate.

figure_4.title: Figure 4.
figure_4.caption: Chemical structures of selected vitamins showing anti-NMSC effect.

figure_5.title: Figure 5.
figure_5.caption: Chemical structures of selected alkaloids showing anti-NMSC effect.

figure_6.title: Figure 6.
figure_6.caption: Chemical structures of selected terpenoids showing anti-NMSC effect.

figure_7.title: Figure 7.
figure_7.caption: Chemical structures of selected isothiocyanates showing anti-NMSC effect.

figure_8.title: Figure 8.
figure_8.caption: In SCC, exposure to SFN hinders cancer progression and in vivo metastasis by diminishing arginine methylation at histone 3 (H3). This reduction involves SFN-induced proteasomal degradation of arginine N-methyltransferase 5 (PRMT5) and methylosome protein 50 (MEP50). Both enzymes are responsible for arginine methylation at H3 and H4, respectively, leading to decreased levels of dimethylated arginine 3 at H4 (H4R3me2) [193]. Moreover, using a biotin-tagged SFN analog (Biotin-ITC) and kinetic analysis, it was showed that SFN covalently binds to recombinant type 2 transglutaminase (TG2), irreversibly inhibiting its transamidase activity. This induces an open/extended conformation and partially inhibits GTP binding, which is crucial for maintaining the aggressive SCC phenotype [194].

figure_9.title: Figure 9.
figure_9.caption: Chemical structures of selected cannabinoids showing anti-NMSC effect.

figure_10.title: Figure 10.
figure_10.caption: Chemical structures of selected carotenoids showing anti-NMSC effect.

figure_11.title: Figure 11.
figure_11.caption: Chemical structures of C2 ceramide showing anti-NMSC effect.

claims.sentence: However, recent scientific studies have indicated that cinnamic acid and rosmarinic acid exhibit therapeutic action against head and neck SCC rather than skin SCC (Figure 1) [69,70,71].

Nonetheless, resveratrol’s capacity to target various aspects of tumor development has enhanced its value as a supplementary agent in combination with other treatments, enhancing its efficacy through synergy (Figure 2) [98].
Thus, in this chapter, we focus on the antioxidant activity of flavonoids in the prevention of skin damage (Figure 3).

While promising, the efficacy and safety of these vitamins, particularly at pharmacological levels, warrant further clinical investigation to optimize their use in NMSC therapeutic strategies (Figure 4).
It was also demonstrated that the alkaloid fraction of Z. carinata exhibited the highest potential as an anti-inflammatory agent (Figure 5) [154].
Notably, carnosic acid, carnosol, and geraniol have been researched for their effects on SCC of the head and neck rather than skin SCC (Figure 6) [157,158,159].

It is essential to acknowledge, however, that investigations into benzyl isothiocyanate, allyl isothiocyanate, and phenethyl isothiocyanate mainly concentrate on their effects on head and neck or esophageal SCC and not on skin SCC (Figure 7) [179,180,181].
This induces an open/extended conformation and partially inhibits GTP binding, which is crucial for maintaining the aggressive SCC phenotype (Figure 8) [194].
Therefore, AEA could be a potential topical agent for the elimination of these types of skin cancer (Figure 9) [201,202].
Research indicates that antioxidant carotenoids such as lycopene, fucoxanthin, and astaxanthin may play a significant role in skin photoprotection (Figure 10).

Synthetic variants such as C2 ceramide are created to emulate natural ceramides’ structure and functions, which is important for research and therapeutic applications, especially in regulating cell cycle, survival, proliferation, differentiation, and immune responses, often through the modulation of proteins like Protein Kinase C (PKC) isoforms, including atypical Protein Kinase C zeta (PKCζ) (Figure 11) [221,222].
However, recent scientific studies have indicated that cinnamic acid and rosmarinic acid exhibit therapeutic action against head and neck SCC rather than skin SCC (Figure 1) [69,70,71].

Nonetheless, resveratrol’s capacity to target various aspects of tumor development has enhanced its value as a supplementary agent in combination with other treatments, enhancing its efficacy through synergy (Figure 2) [98].
Thus, in this chapter, we focus on the antioxidant activity of flavonoids in the prevention of skin damage (Figure 3).
